captions.text: Today I'm going to be showing you exactly how I can turn this bit of road kill
this bit of dead meat
into a trap
What I've decided to do here
is - I'm on a dry creek bed which
is 150 meters
south of the road
and I've picked an area which is nice and cool, there's a bit of shade here
but most importantly
there's sand -
I can dig, I can dig a lot easier
Now the reason I've picked this area is
that this place is nice and open and already I can start to see the hawks
their already keen on me - I'll show you, I'll show you exactly what they are doing
So what these guys are doing, these hawks, is surveying
Their doing these rounds - watching and watching
And they've seen me pull the carcass off the road, and their thinking what's this guy doing here,
what's this scavenger doing here?
So this is where I set the trap,
right here in the sand.
There are two key things with doing this
when capturing a predatory bird,
first things first.
A: He can't see you, you have to be well disguised. And B:
You have to make sure he does not smell you, so that's where all this intestinal,
all this intestinal fluid
is absolutely prime in covering
prime in covering any sort of tracks
you may have left
so it's grabbing all that sort of stuff
running all along ya'
so that way
you mask
every little bit of scent
that there is
The whole key thing with this game is you need to smell like your pray item
you need to smell - if he can smell a predator like me lurking in the sand
there's no way he's going to be coming near, no way
I've got to be smelling exactly the same as this guy, exactly the same
Well, I missed him ... he'll be back
Gotcha mate, I've been waiting and waiting
and I finally got one
This guy here is known as the Swamp Hawk
and I'll tell ya' what, they've been circling and circling
and finally this guys' landed, your alright mate -
finally this guy's landed
and I've been able to grab him, hey your alright, your alright mate
Let's get this out oft of the way
There we have the Swamp Hawk, he's absolutely beautiful isn't he, absolutely gorgeous
The trick of the trade using these carcass traps
is you can catch them -
all you gotta do is be patient, very very patient - still and wait and wait and wait
As long as you smell like the carcass
even if he can pick out your skin coloration, even if he can pick
out your eyes
as long as you stay still, you don't move -
at the end of the day these beautiful birds pick up on motion
their absolute motion detectors, you could see the first time he came down, he took off
but this time
I got you mate, and there's several of them flying around and around
and I knew sooner or later an opportunity was gonna come our way, and finally I got him

comments.author: Sula Bintley

comments.text:
STAGED AND FAKE!

I've watched a number of these videos now.  Every species you catch and 
film is exhausted and generally injured in some way (while this one looks 
more tame than anything else...you must have kept it in a hot box until you 
needed him/her.  Camera tricks of the worst kind.  You never actually show 
the catch or much of the abuse you perform. 
You are an embarrassment to conservation and education and you, sir, are 
100% a fraud.  No wild freshly caught bird would ever act this way.  You 
tire out your subjects for the camera to make yourself look brave.  You are 
offensive and cruel.

Since you seem to want fame so much, you'll likely get it, but for your 
disrespect to wildlife and nothing more.  Like a poacher, only worse 
because they aren't pretending to be heroic. 

Want to prove your worth?  Show us the uncut footage next time.  Not the 
lie you want to portray.﻿

comments.text:
I don't think you need to mask your smell at all. Most birds sense of smell 
is bad due to their disproportionately small olfactory bulbs (part of the 
brain specialized in smell) while their occipital lobes are 
disproportionately large (part of brain designated for vision). ﻿

comments.author: Boola Bear

comments.text:
+rodrigo fresco

How are they suspicious ? You think that once it's being caught on camera 
that automatically means that it can only be a setup ? Or because he seems 
to catch them rather "too quickly" for it to be true ?

Here's one word for you "Editing".

When an animal documentary channel shows a video footage of any 
animal/plant species hunting in action, they must go through a ridiculously 
long process of stalking and editing to capture the "interesting" part :

1) They must gather intel about the subject (plant/animal), in order to 
find it's location, his behavior and under wich circumstances it hunts, all 
in order to survey it.
2) Finding the best camera angle and programming both it's settings and 
that of the microphone, in order to get the cleanest sound/video possible.
3) *waiting*.
4) Getting the footage back to the studio and editing the *hours* of 
useless boring video in loop until finding the "interesting" part, cutting 
it from the rest and editing it for the documentary.

That's video editing in the grand lines.

I don't really get why "finding" animals and/or plants is perceived 
automatically weird or suspicious when relating to a video footage - 
whatever the footage for what it means. When you go on wikipedia looking 
for an animal or a plant, you can easily get it's biography by just writing 
it's name and acessing it a single click. Of course it doesn't mean that it 
makes you an expert on the subject, but those informations already manage 
to give you a considerable insight on it by telling you almost everything 
about it : what are the perceptive senses on wich it rely the most ? Those 
that he do not use ? When does he act ? Where ? At wich time of the day ? 
Under witch meteorological conditions does or doesn't it move ? What are 
his preys/predators ? How does he act in presence of those ? etc. etc. It's 
a long process of collecting and treating datas accurately that, once 
processed, allows the hunter to develop and effective strategy in order to 
capture the subject (plant/animal) he's hunting. *It is the same process 
that allowed humans to effectively hunt absolutely ANY species on earth 
throughout the millenars, and never ended being refined all along since 
ancient time*.

As a matter of fact : *absolutely not a single species on Earth ever 
achieved to hunt so many other species, in both diversity and dangerosity, 
nearly as much as man*. Every single species accurately documented *has 
been hunted* at least a dozen times by humans from all regions across the 
globe : *that is fact*.

So please, explain me, how in the unholy name of balls could anyone in it's 
right mind consider "weird" for a human being to find and hunt an animal in 
the wild, when that is exactly what our ancestors did *FOR HUNDREDS OF 
THOUSANDS OF YEARS* ?

with the hawk already in his hands?   Someone could have just handed him

not true. look up any number of falconry trapping videos and you will see 
this is typical behavior of a trapped hawk. the fallacy, however, was the 
talk about scent. hawks don't hunt by scent, they hunt by sight. among 
birds of prey, vultures are unique in that they are one of th few that have 
a keen sense of smell. but i've never tried laying underneath a dead 
rotting carcass to capture a hawk so what do i know!
